Hawking radiation

Mar 29, 2019

I took a course on general relativity last year, and since then, I’ve maintained a casual interest in black holes. They seem like a good test ground for a lot of theoretical concepts. In this (mostly expository) post, I want to describe a few foundational results in this area.

Suppose we now study a quantum theory on Schwarzschild spacetime. Since expectation values of operators should be analytic functions of coordinates, they should be well-defined on the Euclidean-signature spacetime obtained by Wick rotation. As we saw above, this forces all operators to be periodic with period ; so the Schwarzschild black hole in equilibrium must be surrounded by a temperature bath of temperature determined by . If there’s nothing else around the black hole, then it must be emitting radiation at that temperature.
